Within a year, 13 long-term homeless young people, aged 11 to 15, had made themselves known to the service, whilst many more had passed through with some accommodation crisis.

There is not one crisis bed in Ulladulla of any sort, so they slept at friends' places, in trees, in caves or broke into holiday houses. Several of the young people had been left behind when their caregiver took up with someone new who did not get on with that child. They moved interstate whilst these children were at school and simply just left them behind. Nothing was done because it was too hard and there was no use if they did not want the kids anyway. No-one believed the youth centre. Even when the young people decided to go public, people said, `It can't be true.'

Point 2 is that the recommendations of the Prime Minister's youth homelessness task force are excellent. The task force investigated the range of innovative interventions possible at every stage of family development to see if services could better resource families. The focus was on ways of improving the support available for young people in the early stages of homelessness, or at the risk of becoming homeless, and their relationships with their families. The emphasis was to be on early intervention initiatives aimed at reconciliation with family members.

Point 3 is that again I want to emphasise the difficulty of being part of a large region like the Illawarra. On the basis of the pilot program's recommendation, the federal government then prioritised those areas most in need of services. Kiama and Shoalhaven, both part of my electorate of Gilmore, were ranked number two in New South Wales, along with Wollongong and Shellharbour. Accordingly, tenders have been called for an agency to provide these services to the Illawarra as a whole. It is highly unlikely that a small township can put in a bid for a tender that large. This means that, by default, the cities that win the tenders—in this case Wollongong—have also been given the pilot program. The service is then based in that city, and the services to other localities are contracted out to local agencies or simply not provided. The local agencies, if they take up an opportunity to subcontract, receive the minimum resources to provide the service, all the cream having been sucked off by the brokering agency. This often involves long hours of travel to meetings where the smaller agencies hold no sway, know nobody and profit least.

Is this regional tendering really a best practice example of client-driven service or is it yet another example of departmental efficiency-driven service? Logistically, it is too difficult, costly and time consuming to provide services over a large area and to a large number of service points, which is precisely why the department itself does not want to service the smaller areas. However, if the department with all its resources cannot do this, what on earth makes it think that a small, underfunded service—mainly run by volunteers—can do it? The decision defies logic. Just within each of these three regions of Gilmore, there are similar difficulties with service between the various towns. Indeed, it is not for the want of innovative programs that services do not extend here.

Point 4, to name but one program, Millie's RaveRatz is not just a flophouse but a place with a pathway. One resident, Millie Kellett, has developed a wonderful concept that is about to bear fruit. This concept involves a family of animals, RaveRatz, around whom a syndicated comic strip revolves. The funds generated from this strip, and its spin-off commercial enterprises, will go to establishing small and appropriate forms of accommodation for each of the stages of homelessness intervention. Millie, who is working with Father Chris Riley from YOTS and other worthy and high profile `can-do' sponsors, has a vision of Ratz business that will fund further services deemed necessary by the young people themselves while also creating jobs and business opportunities. For example, when there are few jobs to be had or vacancies require skills other than those available, how does a young person gain a rite of passage to create that job? The Work for the Dole program provides such avenues.
I repeat what I started with: Gilmore has no accommodation for the homeless, yet we have the second highest incidence of young people with nowhere to go. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—I congratulate the honourable member for Gilmore on bringing forward this motion and, in doing so, raising the serious issue of youth homelessness. Too many young people find themselves without a safe home to go to. I can only imagine the feelings of insecurity and desolation that young people in that situation have to deal with. That is a tragedy for those individuals and a sign of a wider failure on the part of communities and governments. Clearly, the government has a responsibility to help and protect young homeless people at their moment of crisis, as they are amongst the most disadvantaged in our community. Beyond that there is a responsibility for the government to provide young people with the support they need to escape homelessness and the long-term damage it can do to them. This motion recognises that responsibility on the part of government and invites us to focus on this government's response to the increasing numbers of young homeless people.

speech.para: Nobody would stand here and say that there is a simple solution to the problem of homelessness. Each young person left home or was forced out of home for a different and very personal reason. Each young person has a different experience of being homeless and the key to turning the corner and finding a way out of homelessness will be different for each person. Addressing homelessness is always going to be a big ask, but understanding it would be a good start. Sadly, the government appears to have fallen at this first hurdle. All the government had to do was to learn from the findings of its homelessness task force. That report highlighted the importance of the relationship between early intervention programs and other support programs for young people in the areas of supported accommodation, education and employment. You do not have an answer to youth homelessness unless it involves all of those areas in a coordinated way. The government's focus on youth homelessness is better than nothing, but it is too narrow and inadequately funded to be truly effective.

When I talk to the youth workers in my local community, the message is very clear. Ultimately, addressing homelessness is not just about providing a bed and a feed for young people. As one of our local workers said to me, `Sure that keeps the young people alive but it doesn't give them a life to go on with.' Ideally, it is about recognising the young person not as a person without a home but, first and foremost, as a person without hope and working from there. The emotional needs of young homeless people are just as important, if not more important, than the physical needs.

The youth workers in Rocky understand this, but they are not in a position to provide the sort of assistance that young people are crying out for due to the inadequate funding this government provides to the community sector. The $60 million allocated to the Youth Homelessness Early Intervention Program that the government is so proud of went to only a small number of programs around Australia. Meanwhile, the youth workers in Rocky are doing their utmost to help the young people accessing their services but knowing all the while that they are really only meeting their most basic physical needs.

In the meantime, the issues that led to homelessness remain unresolved and usually worsen. The young people frequently rely on drugs to mask their pain. Before long, the options that could have been open to them with immediate and appropriate intervention by youth workers and crisis services start to close off. Youth workers know all this, but in Rocky the lack of funding does not allow them to address it however much they would like to. This is not an exaggeration. I have been on the management committee of our local youth shelter for almost three years and I have sat through meeting after meeting when we have discussed the absolute necessity of having extra workers to provide the sort of case management that young people accessing our service so desperately need if they are to rebuild their relationships and their future.

This is what young people in crisis in Rocky can expect when they find themselves homeless: they can go to the youth shelter, called Jack's House, in Rockhampton and get a bed for the night and some food. There is a staff member present each night to provide support for young people but, because of the lack of funding, the shelter shuts during the day. We do not have the money to employ a worker to run programs or support young people at the shelter during the day. The workers can easily identify the kind of help the young people need—whether it is intensive personal and family counselling or just the basics like budgeting—but it is just not possible to provide that on the funding we presently receive. It is quite clear that, to achieve results for young people at the shelter, they need individual case management, but to do that we would need a minimum of two staff on at all times. We cannot do that with our present finances. Luckily, we can refer many of our young residents to another local service called Youthtrek—a service funded under the government's JPET Program. It is quite clear, from what the workers at Youthtrek tell me, that the fact that their clients go back to a shelter without additional support is very counterproductive in their progress.

While I congratulate the member for Gilmore on raising this issue, unfortunately—from what I see in my own local communi ty—her motion does not go far enough. The government will not solve homelessness unless it is prepared to properly fund all communities to address the causes and long-term implications of homelessness. Basically, it has to do what its own task force urged a year ago—that is, to provide funding at appropriate levels to allow adequate national coverage. That call came a year ago. The young people of central Queensland are still waiting. They need that help straightaway.

talk.start.para: —Youth homelessness is certainly not a new phenomenon in this or in any other country. But the fact that we have so many—an estimated 20,000 young people—without a home is a sad commentary on our society. It is a reflection, I believe, of several things, especially the breakdown of our families, a lack of communication within families, more and more dysfunctional families and rising divorce and separation rates. The same issues that impact on our nuclear families also impact on the extended family and on other social institutions which used to come to the rescue in the event of a crisis within the primary care network.

speech.para: For each of these 20,000-odd young people who are homeless there is a long story, in many cases, of distress, interruption to study and work, a greater incidence of ill-health and susceptibility to violence, prostitution, crime and despair. The young people in my electorate—the electorate of Macquarie—are not immune from these problems. The same factors that affect young people everywhere, the same factors that put stress on our families, also affect families in my electorate. In the Blue Mountains we have supported accommodation services provided by Open House, yet Open House is badly in need of more resources. In the last year it had 146 referrals from welfare workers, yet it was able to place only 25 young people—that is, the other 121 had to be turned away; they could not be helped.

In the Hawkesbury area, again we have insufficient resources. We have two groups providing accommodation. There are five short-term places at Fairview for 14- to 18-year-olds and five medium-term places at the Hayshed for 12- to 18-year-olds. This is not nearly enough. In addition to this, there is a great need for special services for other young people. For instance, there is no accommodation in the whole Hawkesbury region for teenage single mums. These young people are forced, tragically, to move on and to move further away from their support networks of friends.

There is a need for governments at all levels to do more to help our homeless young people. The federal government—this government—has seen this as a high priority. Early in 1996 it established a youth homelessness task force to look at the problems and to fund some pilot programs based on early intervention, focused on family relations and strengthening the family unit. It has made a commitment of $60 million over the next four years to establish centres to provide early intervention services. One of these pilot programs, the Nepean family integration project—auspiced by the Nepean Youth Accommodation Service in my neighbouring electorate, the electorate of Lindsay—is about to expand to assist families also in the Hawkesbury and Blue Mountains areas.

Its approach is that prevention is better than cure. Its approach is one of early intervention to assist young people and to help families at risk before homelessness becomes a problem. It works with Centrelink to identify the needs of families and to provide access to support services. It assists schools to identify behavioural indicators of young people in crisis, young people at risk, and to provide counselling services for those young people in conjunction with their families. It provides family mediation services for young people at risk and their families, aimed at reconciliation and, hopefully, the prevention of the irretrievable breakdown that leads to young people leaving home. It also works at encouraging those who have left home to be reconciled to their families, to tackle the underlying causes and to restore their relationship with their families.

The good news is that reports from the Nepean family integration project, reports from schools in the area and from community youth workers are that this pilot project is having a positive impact. Young people who were at risk seem to be able to work with their families, work through their problems and to stay at home. I look forward to seeing this very valuable project extended to schools in the Hawkesbury and in the Blue Mountains.

Early intervention is a key to tackling the problems of youth homelessness. The government is making an increased commitment to early intervention. We need to see the states also making progress in early intervention and supported accommodation programs for those who have, for whatever reason, been forced to leave home. The real challenge for us as a community, the real challenge for us as a society, is to address the underlying causes which create homelessness, to work at strengthening our families, to reduce the incidence of family breakdown, divorce, separation and the financial stresses that our families face and to increase the levels of commitment so our families stay together. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I appreciate the opportunity to discuss this issue, in particular, in relation to my own regional community of Bass. The risk of homelessness amongst young people in Northern Tasmania is on the increase. Decreasing employment opportunities and changes to federal government policies such as the common youth allowance have significantly contributed to this increase. The policies implemented by the Howard government have done nothing to address the problem.

speech.para: So what services are currently offered to young homeless people in Northern Tasmania and what are the current service provision deficiencies in Northern Tasmania? Put quite simply, there is a lack of federal funding. Currently there are 14 units available between the four crisis accommodation facilities operating in Bass, Karinya—a young women's shelter—Fusion, Anglicare and the Northern Youth Shelter for young men, all of which can refer clients to the units which are managed by Anglicare. All of these facilities are based in the wider Launceston area.

But young people who are homeless require more than simply a roof over their heads. Outreach services are limited and underfunded where provided. Outreach services, as we know, are vital in order for young people to be able to work towards a long-term resolution of their homelessness. The Northern Youth Shelter in Launceston, for example, is not funded to provide outreach services. According to the manager of the shelter, this inadequacy results in young men staying at the shelter for longer than they should as `specialised housing arrangements' with the department require an assurance that these outreach services will be provided. And rightly so. Not to provide basic outreach services to these young people would set them up to fail. So the cycle of homelessness would recommence, with the young person again requiring to access the shelter.

The federal government must provide financial assistance to shelters to provide this ongoing assistance to enable young homeless people to move out of shelters into their own homes. It is better for the individuals and a better way to manage homelessness in a more holistic and productive manner. Organisations funded to provide services to young homeless people are desperately underfunded, with a heavy reliance being placed on the goodwill of workers in these organisations to work far beyond the measures required by their employment.

Not only are outreach services required to assist young people to move beyond homelessness, but physical improvements are required to modernise and improve the living conditions in the Northern Youth Shelter. Shelters must be relatively pleasant to live in if they are going to be successful in reducing the numbers of young people who are living on our streets. There must be some acknowledgment that these young people require more than just a house; they require ongoing support.

Fusion in Launceston have funding as an organisation to house young people in units, but these young people need more than just a house and the funds are simply not available to make these places more comfortable and able to be lived in. For example, one of the units I visited recently was without such simple things as curtains.

Young people in regional areas such as Northern Tasmania are at greater risk of homelessness due to the decreasing opportunities in their regional communities. Reduced access to education and training opportunities is another reason for increased homelessness. Targeted programs aimed at those at risk of homelessness have been cut by the Howard government. For example, the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre ran a successful program which provided young Aborigines at risk of homelessness with an opportunity to increase their employment skills.

As a community we need to develop intervention programs, identifying young people in the community who are at risk of becoming homeless and providing opportunities to prevent them from becoming homeless. The federal government must also support educational opportunities in regional Tasmania. Hostels in northern Tasmania once used by rural northern Tasmanians are struggling due to a lack of federal support. The federal government must intervene and offer support to these hostels in order to enable rural students equitable access to years 11 and 12. In Tasmania we have the lowest retention rates in Australia, behind the Northern Territory. We must actively support education as a realistic and achievable option.

Educational opportunities and equitable access for our young people to education will drastically impact upon the high incidence of youth homelessness. Another crucial issue is knowledge of the existence of services and their level of accessibility. I acknowledge the federal government's specific commitment to reducing that risk and providing appropriate accommodation services for young people. However, I must profess some concern at the process. Since December 1998 Senator Newman has announced the Youth Homelessness Early Intervention Program no less than four times. Young people need real policy—not just lip-service. Action, and not just words, is required.

At the Bass Youth Conference young people who participated asserted that they were sick and tired of hearing what politicians want to do, without seeing any action. They clearly said that they want options. Quite frankly, the repeated announcement of a national program boasting delivery of $1.30 per young person per day is a sign of how desperate the federal government has become to find good news stories in the youth portfolio.

I too support the call on governments at all levels to cooperate with one another to identify, fund and implement programs of assistance. We all need to consult with young people to ascertain what services they want to address youth homelessness. The federal government must also implement a program designed to work with young people, in particular those who are at Ashley Children's Detention Centre. This is a facility used for young offenders and sometimes neglected children statewide. Any program must take place prior to them coming out so that the young people can clearly identify options.

In particular, there is a specific need for the government to assist in the provision of outreach services to young people with special needs. This issue came to my notice recently when a young profoundly deaf person who was homeless in my electorate was not able to access an outreach service at all. States desperately require Commonwealth funding to provide outreach and specialised services for young people in these sorts of situations.
In conclusion, young homeless people require an extension of existing services through federal funding for the provision of outreach services. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I strongly commend this motion. When I first rose in this place, I spoke of the important family bonds that most of us enjoy and hold sacred. As I said, families tell us who we are and let us dream about what we can become. Sadly, thousands of Australian children are not growing up with that sense of self and opportunity to fulfil their potential. I am speaking of those who, for many reasons, find themselves alienated from their families and are homeless.

speech.para: Homelessness is like a silent disease in our community. Most of us return to our comfortable homes each evening, largely unaware of the thousands of our fellow Australians who have no home in which they can take shelter or comfort. For decades, the issue of homelessness was overlooked by the Labor government, passed off as a state matter. I acknowledge that, for the most part, the problem does fall under the jurisdiction of state governments. But the care and welfare of our children is not something that can be bound by jurisdiction. They are the inherent responsibility of each of us as legislators, as parents and as compassionate human beings. Labor's approach in office was characteristically big on rhetoric and short on practical achievement. Who could ever forget Bob Hawke's grand promise that by 1990 no Australian child would live in poverty?

In stark contrast to the hollow rhetoric of Labor, I am very proud of the fact that, within weeks of our election to government in 1996, John Howard established the Prime Ministerial Youth Homeless Taskforce. He did not pretend that there would be a simple solution, but in his own stoic and determined way he set about laying the groundwork for a long-term improvement in our homeless problem. The task force was made up of representatives from community organisations working at the coalface of this problem: the Salvation Army, the Society of St Vincent de Paul, the Wesley Mission and Anglicare.

Twenty-six pilot projects were established around Australia, aimed at trialling a range of early intervention and family reconciliation strategies. These pilots proved so successful that in this year's budget we have provided an unprecedented $60 million over the next four years for the establishment of youth homelessness early intervention programs. Working on the commonsense approach that prevention is better than cure, the early intervention program is aimed at resolving family difficulties and ensuring that young people at risk of becoming homeless, as well as their families, are offered mediation and counselling to resolve their differences. In the pilot program more than two-thirds of the families involved were reconciled, and even in cases where young people had already left home more than one-third returned home to live with one or both of their parents.

It is fitting that the final report of the Prime Ministerial Youth Homeless Taskforce is entitled Putting families in the picture. For years, there has been a tendency to focus only on the individual rather than taking a whole of family approach. I am heartened that the focus is shifting.

In addition to early intervention, we have allocated an extra $25 million for the prevention of domestic violence, which is identified as the main cause of youth homelessness. Further, the Howard government is ensuring real assistance for those who are currently homeless. As this motion outlines, we have allocated increased funding for the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program. An evaluation of this program released in April this year found that it can lay claim to being a world-class innovative program for homeless people. The report concludes that its main strength is that it is nationally coordinated and operates in a joint pool of Commonwealth-state resources.

This motion calls on all governments to work together to address homelessness, as do recommendations 4, 10, 16, 17 and 18 of the report Putting families in the picture. Quite simply, it makes sense to do so, and I certainly welcome the Howard government's commitment in this regard. As I said at the outset, there are no simple solutions. Youth homelessness is a symptom of family breakdown, financial pressures, unemployment and lack of opportunity. These are fundamentals that the Howard government is working very hard to address, and we have made gains in reducing financial pressure on families by lowering interest rates and by creating more jobs, with our youth unemployment now at its lowest level in more than a decade.

Importantly, we have given the opportunity for long-term unemployed people to contribute to our community and gain valuable work skills through a Work for the Dole program. The simple fact is that things just will not change overnight. We must strive for long-term solutions to youth homelessness while at the same time providing resources to help make a difference right now. The Howard government will continue to do exactly that as long as there are still young people who have no place to call home.

talk.start.para: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on this motion. I say at the outset that this is a very serious issue that we are discussing in the House today. It is important to place this issue in context. The people who work for the Central Gippsland Accommodation and Support Service, CGASS, spoke to me about this issue last week and advised me that they have children as young as 10 and 11 years old presenting as being homeless for their service. Ten and 11 years old—that is grade 4 and grade 5. These children are not even out of primary school, and they are homeless.

speech.para: There are a lot of problems relating to youth homelessness which are not about much apart from parenting skills. Those parents who have children who are at risk of homelessness would recognise that a lot of the problem relates to that situation. They recognise that the problems lie with parenting skills, and they want to go about getting some support in teaching them how to be better parents and how to better care for their children. Unfortunately, when these parents find themselves deficient in one part of parenting and put their hand up and say, `We would like to get a little bit of help; we would like to get a little bit of support from government in making ourselves a better family,' there are not the services available to assist them in that regard. Unfortunately, whilst there are a lot of good families who want to make themselves better families and become better parents, and obviously reduce the risk of their children becoming homeless, there are not the services available to them to assist them in that regard.

We need to be sensitive as well to the types of programs that we offer to families who are going about the business of improving their parenting skills. We need to be sensitive in not calling any of the programs that we offer to those people `Struggling parents programs', `Bad parents programs' or any of those things. We need to be sensitive that there is often—unfortunately—a great deal of embarrassment that people feel in accessing these types of services. We need to be sensitive to that.

It is just as important to recognise that it is not just kids from working-class backgrounds who suffer from homelessness. It occurs in families from all walks of life. For my own part, I have to confess that I never thought that this would be an issue which would affect middle-class families, but the people in the field advise me that there is just as great a likelihood of children from middle-class backgrounds getting themselves involved in homelessness as there is for children from other walks of life.

Unquestionably, the Howard government's changes to the common youth allowance have made homelessness worse in Australia. Young adults living at home now regularly have to ask parents for money in order to get the basics of life, simply because they are no longer eligible for the common youth allowance. So we are sending these people a mixed message. On the one hand, we are preaching to them that they need to take responsibility for themselves whilst, on the other hand, we are telling them that they need to be dependent on mum and dad to get a few dollars each week. This represents a serious contradiction and is something which the Howard government needs to face up to if we are to move forward at all on this issue.

When talking about youth homelessness, people regularly refer to refuges. I want to make the point that refuges are not appropriate for all young people, simply because young people tend not to be street smart enough to be able to make their way through in a refuge. By placing them in a refuge we can often be placing them at risk. Young people need to be given the option of being housed with families. This is an important point to make because this is about involving the community in dealing with some of these issues, making the community a part of the solution.

I want to mention briefly the experience I had at Warragul only last week where a forum was called to discuss homelessness and other serious issues affecting the community there. A woman who lives on a farm there mentioned how much benefit she got from having homeless children come and spend time with her family every Christmas. This was not only something which those homeless people got benefit from but also something which her children got benefit from. It improved their understanding and empathy with young homeless people. In looking for solutions to youth homelessness, we need to be serious about engaging with the community and making them very much a part of the solution.

talk.start.para: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Please proceed.

—Today in question time in the other place Senator Chris Schacht asked a question of Senator Alston regarding me and my comments regarding a visit to Tibet last week. I will not take the time of the House to read the whole of the Hansard of that, but there are five specific instances where he has misrepresented me. The first:

speech.para: . . . does the government agree—
with me, that is—
that the current Chinese rule is better for the Tibetan people than any alternative?
Never at any time did I make that statement or that claim. I said that things in Tibet now are better than when I visited it in 1992. The second point is that he referred to:
. . . Mr Nehl's view that the only role the Chinese army plays in Tibet is to protect the borders . . .

I never inferred that that was the only role. I tried to draw to the attention of people who were not aware that Tibet has borders with five countries, including two nuclear powers, and that the protection of their borders was a significant role for the Chinese army. The third point was:
. . . Mr Nehl has admitted that he did not speak to any Tibetan people on his visit . . .

I spoke to many Tibetan people. They were, of course, members of the TAR government or their agencies—schoolteachers and the like. I do not speak Tibetan. I do not speak Chinese. The option of wandering off and chatting with ordinary Tibetans was unfortunately not available to me. The fourth point was:
. . . he only saw what his Chinese hosts wanted him to see . . .
That is incorrect. I set the itinerary for my visit to Tibet. We went where I wanted to go. The fifth and final point is that he asked:
Will the government take Mr Nehl's report on Tibet seriously or will it be filed under `tourist snow job'?
The report I submit will be a serious, fair and objective report, not a snow job.

debate.para: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Oyster Industry

talk.start.para: —I wish to speak about a grievance today. My grievance is with the government that went to the people of Australia just one year ago with a promise that under the new tax system no-one would be worse off and, `We'll look after small business.' In the past year I have listened to the concerns of many small business people who are terrified of what the changes in the tax laws will do to them. But today I want to talk about a specific industry that is facing major problems, an uncertain future, an industry which is a regional industry and would employ in the order of 1,000 people directly, and many more indirectly, on the North Coast of New South Wales. That industry is the oyster industry, and it is being hounded by an unfair tax system. Anyone who knows anything about this industry knows only too well how oyster farmers are continually battling the elements, the environment, disease in their oysters and the community perception of whether it is safe to eat oysters or not.

speech.para: I am sure many members can recall the disaster that befell Wallis Lakes in the north of my electorate of Paterson only three years ago that prevented any oysters being harvested or sold from that area for over 12 months. This is an industry that has a history of boom and bust. Those conditions are almost always beyond the control of the grower—be it the cost of purification, inundation by the Pacific or Gigas species or contamination by polluted run-off. Now we can add a new dimension to the problems faced by the oyster growers. And that new problem is the Australian Taxation Office.

The reason is that the oyster farmers are being asked to change their method of valuing their stock. In other words, they are being treated like retailers who buy in stock and retail it for profit, where the stock is a real, tangible asset with a definitive value. The oyster industry is far from that scenario. The Oyster Farmers Association have argued that oysters should be excluded in the same way as vegetables, fruit, timber, et cetera because of the impact on those industries of section 70-10 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997.

As I have already pointed out, the variables facing the oyster farmer make it a precarious industry. The fact that there are three-year-old oysters on racks ready to harvest in six months time does not mean that a single oyster will necessarily be harvested. A `kill' can wipe out virtually an entire oyster crop in 24 hours. Essentially, my grievance is that theorists in the Australian Taxation Office are treating the oyster industry in a purely economic rationalist way with no account for the realistic problems that this industry faces. They are asking the oyster farmers to place a value on their unrealised asset—the asset of oysters on racks that if harvested will be of value but may be completely lost due to natural phenomena. That value, however it can be counted, will be regarded as income in the opening year.

For the past two years, the Oyster Farmers Association of New South Wales have repeatedly called on the Australian Taxation Office to give them a realistic consideration. So far, their calls have fallen on deaf ears. They have asked that their oyster crop has an opening value rather than a zero value. This would considerably reduce the paper or virtual income in that first year. That means they would pay tax only on the change in value of their stock. Over the first financial year, that would give them some relief. It would not allow the entire value of all stock at the end of the first year to be taxable. That in itself is a horrific thought. A number of oyster farmers have told me that if this form of accounting comes in they will be forced to leave the industry.

I call on the Treasurer and the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry as a matter of urgency to inject some commonsense into this equation and to assure the oyster farmers that they can go on accounting for their crop in the traditional way. They deserve recognition and respect as a responsible group of people who employ large numbers of people in regional Australia, both directly and indirectly. Of course, they face another tax problem related directly to the way they are treated by the GST.

In conclusion, let me say that the oyster industry is a vibrant industry. It is a responsible industry that historically has faced enormous hurdles to allow it to survive. How ironic it would be, at a time it is at its most technologically advanced stage, using best practice and producing an excellent product, if it was killed off because of the intransigence of a hungry tax office that is all too anxious to classify industries so that the government's return is maximised through the tax system, rather than to allow an industry to be treated in a manner that will allow it to flourish and maximise its purpose in regional Australia as an employer.

talk.start.para: —I want to take this opportunity today to send our most heartfelt concern, safe wishes and hope to everyone affected by the tragedy in East Timor in the past two weeks. Many honourable members come into this chamber during grievance debates to talk about the wrongs that we believe should be put right. There can be no greater wrong than the horrific and systematic acts of violence that have been wrought on the people of East Timor in the wake of their historic and overwhelming vote for independence. While we are still unaware of the exact extent of the loss of life and property destruction, we can be assured from all reports that it is of mass proportions. To see the innocent families that have been torn asunder, the homes that have been ruined and the fear on the faces of the refugees that we have welcomed to Darwin could not possibly fail to stir the deepest emotions of compassion and sympathy.

speech.para: I share the anger and outrage of many local residents who have contacted my office to express their concerns and support for the East Timorese. I share their frustration and that of the Prime Minister that it has taken some time to ensure that international forces, headed by Australia, could rightly and properly go to the aid of East Timor. I know that were it not for the determined efforts of the Prime Minister we would still be waiting for action. The Prime Minister has been tenacious in gathering worldwide support for the international forces. He has been insistent on America's involvement and UN support for our troops. And well he should. It is to his credit that the international forces have gone to East Timor with the support of the elected Indonesian government. To do otherwise would have been to invite even greater danger to our young soldiers and to jeopardise our own security in this region.

I find it very ironic that the same people who screamed loudly in the first few days that something—anything—must be done and advocated just sending our forces straightaway are now critical that our relationship with Indonesia has been set back. I ask them: just how much worse would it have been if we had sent armed troops without Indonesia's agreement? Without UN and international support, exactly what sort of situation would we have been sending our troops into? I am deeply disappointed that many members on the opposite side, including the Leader of the Opposition, have sought to make political mileage out of this tragedy. It is all very well to say that something must be done, but it takes a lot more courage and guts to actually come up with a solution. This has not been a simple solution by any stretch of the imagination. It has required diplomacy, negotiations and understanding. I am appalled that the opposition leader, particularly as he is a former Minister for Defence and should know much better, has yet again taken the easy route of opposition—complaint and criticism—instead of supporting the government's international efforts.

But I guess we have come to expect that and I do not want to take up any more time today on Labor's stance, nor on their total inaction during the 13 years that they were in government. I want to focus on the many people who have been deeply affected by this tragedy. I refer naturally to the East Timorese—those who have lost loved ones, those who have been forced out of their homes into West Timor, those who have sought safety in the hills and have faced all sorts of difficulties, and the thousands whom we have welcomed into Darwin and who are now settling in safe havens throughout the nation. I say to the East Timorese: the Australian people are deeply sympathetic. We understand your desire for independence and democracy. We believe in your fundamental right to safety. We are angered that you have been forced out of your homes and we have pledged ourselves to helping you in any way we can.

Of course, the East Timorese have been the most horribly and directly affected by the events of the past few weeks. I would also like to acknowledge the brave efforts of the many Australian and UN workers who were assisting in the election in East Timor. They faced a very dangerous situation and will no doubt bear the emotional scars of their experiences for many years to come.

There is a very special group of people to whom I especially want to pay tribute today: our service men and women, some of whom are already in East Timor while others are poised to go as part of the international force. Recently I had the pleasure, thanks to Colonel Rainer, of sharing a very relaxed lunch with General Cosgrove. I could not think of a more capable service personnel member to lead this international peace corps. He and his service men and women have our utmost respect, support and safe wishes. Their families, who are waiting here in Australia for their safe return, are also in our thoughts and prayers. As a mother of eight, I can only imagine how frightening it must be for the families of these brave men and women.

Personally, I am extremely proud to represent the service men and women who are based at the Canungra Land Warfare Centre in my electorate. I understand that a number of these local service personnel have been called to assist in East Timor and I send them all the very best of wishes on behalf of all local residents as well as a grateful nation. Last Friday I was pleased to meet with Commandant Bowen, as I regularly do to keep in touch with issues of concern to my local service community. At that discussion I had the pleasure of meeting Major Jock Fraser, who is currently based at Canungra. Major Fraser's son, Lachlan, is Townsville based and has been called on to be part of the international force in East Timor. As Major Fraser spoke of his son, I could see the very genuine concern that I am sure every parent of these service men and women is feeling at this time.

To Lachlan Fraser, who has either just arrived or is about to leave for East Timor, I want to send very special wishes for a happy birthday because today Lachlan turns 21. It is a coming of age no parent would wish for their child. Happy Birthday, Lachlan. Your family is incredibly proud of you. I am sure your mates will help you celebrate in some way today.

For me, having shared seven 21st birthdays with my children and looking forward to my youngest daughter's next year, that really underscores the reality of Australia's involvement in assisting our neighbours in East Timor. We are sending our young men and women into an unexpected, unpredictable and dangerous situation. I do not question for one minute that we should. We have a leadership role to play and a moral duty to protect the innocent people of East Timor from the atrocities being carried out by the militia.

But we should be under no illusions that this is a simple task. It never has been from the beginning, and the decision to commit Australian men and women to any conflict is not one that we should ever take lightly. I believe that the Prime Minister has shown tremendous judgment and wisdom in his handling of this situation to ensure that the Australian-led force could get to East Timor as soon as possible under the safest conditions and—as the Minister for Foreign Affairs said in this House today—in record time.

As I said at the outset, during the grievance debate in this place we often talk about wrongs that must be righted. Today I am acutely aware that, while I am talking about the wrongs committed in East Timor, thousands of young Australians are physically there risking their lives to right those wrongs. Every Australian wishes them well. We all share the hope that the situation in East Timor can be resolved quickly and in peace so that the East Timorese can begin to rebuild their lives in peace and our Australian service men and women can return home safely.

talk.start.para: —The current crisis in East Timor has brought into stark relief a parallel crisis in the international broadcasting capacity of this nation. I refer to the emasculation of Radio Australia which has occurred during the four years of the Howard Government, an emasculation for which we the Australian nation are now paying dearly. In summary, what the Howard government has done over these four years is as follows. It has closed the Darwin/Cox Peninsula transmitters, thereby denying Australia a capacity to broadcast either in English or in Indonesian to central and western Indonesia, as well as to broader South-East Asia. It has halved the operating budget of Radio Australia. It has more than halved the number of foreign language staff working for Radio Australia from 144 down to 68. It has halved the number of Indonesian language staff working for Radio Australia from 16 down to eight. Most critically, it has effectively halved the length of daily programming in the Indonesian language being broadcast; that is, broadcast to those parts of Indonesia which are still capable of actually hearing the transmission.

speech.para: In effect, what we have managed to do is silence our voice in Asia at a time when we are facing arguably this nation's greatest crisis in Asia since 1945. It is extraordinary that those opposite, who pride themselves in the traditions of conservatism and the preservation of national institutions, should have found it so easy to take the broadaxe to Radio Australia, which has been servicing this nation and the region of which we are part since 1939. We now find ourselves standing not only naked but in effect silent in terms of our national capacity to project our message across Indonesia and broader listening audiences in the neighbouring ASEAN states of South-East Asia.

Whereas there is still a signal capable of being heard in Timor and in eastern Indonesia, the reality is that, after 60 years of operation, nearly 90 per cent of Indonesia's population cannot hear our signal. We cannot be heard in Jakarta. We cannot be heard across Java. We cannot be heard in Sumatra. So at a time when there is paramount importance attached to our ability to project our national views on recent developments in East Timor to the rest of the Indonesian nation we have woken up to discover that we have cut our own throat.

We cannot rely upon the bulk of the local Indonesian media to carry a textured or even detailed message about recent developments in East Timor. Certainly the Indonesian media, while being much more liberal than under the New Order regime, cannot be expected to explain to their audience what precisely occurred in East Timor after the 30 August ballot, the precise degree of TNI complicity in militia activities in East Timor, the unfolding humanitarian disaster in West Timor and why Australia, in conjunction with the international community, has found it absolutely essential to participate in a multinational force to stabilise East Timor. The bottom line is that, while some of the quality journals in Jakarta may give some exposure to the Australian perspective on these issues, the bulk of the Indonesian media will not. Nationalism in any country has as its first casualty objectivity—particularly objectivity as it relates to the activities of another nation state. Moreover, we have a continued requirement to communicate with the Indonesian elite, many of whom have traditionally been staunch Radio Australia listeners.

Radio Australia estimated in its submission to the Mansfield review of the ABC that in Indonesia alone it had a regular listening audience of two million. Of course, a regular listening audience of two million is considerably in excess of the broadcast reach of the then Radio Australia and the occasional listeners who tuned into its services. At the time of the Mansfield review, and in a happier period of the Australia-Indonesia relationship, the Jakarta Post of 11 February 1997 stated:

Why do so many Indonesians tune to Radio Australia? One obvious reason is that Radio Australia's reception is good in many areas of Indonesia. . . . Another, and perhaps more significant reason, however, is that Radio Australia, in many cases, satisfy Indonesia's need for non-partisan and accurate information.

Not only have we cut off our capacity to communicate with Indonesian elites and the broad population, I wonder whether Senator Alston and Mr Downer have worked out just how we propose communicating effectively with the thousands of Australian expatriates across Indonesia if the current crisis in our bilateral relationship deteriorates further. If such deterioration occurs and it becomes necessary to evacuate Australian nationals, we need a capacity to get the message out rapidly. The response may be that we could perhaps rely upon Australian Television International. Well, after the government's hatchet job on ATI, you would not exactly hold your breath.

I suppose the second line of defence would be to resort to CNN and the BBC World Service. However, these are not agencies of the Australian government and they do not have as their first responsibility the execution of Australian government policy—even when that policy extends to the consular protection of Australian nationals. Furthermore, there are Australians resident across Indonesia who do not necessarily have access to international television services and whose only effective form of communication is short-wave radio broadcasts. So, once again, will Australians working on mining and exploration services in some of the more remote parts of Indonesia have to rely on the philanthropy of the BBC and VOA? From a consular interest alone, the Howard government has landed the nation and its nationals abroad in an unacceptable set of circumstances.

The previous capacity of Radio Australia's Cox Peninsula transmitters was impressive indeed. One of the great ironies was that the Cox Peninsula facility was constructed as a direct response by the Menzies government to the problems that emerged in the Australia-Indonesia relationship following `konfrontasi'. It was damaged by Cyclone Tracy in 1974, rebuilt in 1981 and modernised in 1993 at a total cost of $50 million. What we had at Cox were three powerful 250-kilowatt transmitters which represented the largest broadcasting station in Australia, as well as representing a global facility of first-class standards. The three transmitters at Cox enabled Radio Australia to broadcast for 24 hours across five different frequencies across all of Indonesia, all of mainland South-East Asia and a large part of the Indian subcontinent, as well as southern and coastal China.

When the Howard government decided to close it down as a consequence of the Mansfield review, it decided to have Radio Australia rely instead on its lower grade transmitters located at Shepparton in Victoria and Branson in Queensland. These transmitters are designed to broadcast to eastern Indonesia, Papua New Guinea and parts of the south-west Pacific. The bottom line is that, at best, we now have one third of our previous geographical reach. In response to the current crisis, I am advised that Radio Australia has been authorised to purchase an additional one hour of broadcasting time per day in Indonesian from an international commercial transmitter located in—wait for it—Taiwan. This bandaid approach to what has become a strategic problem for this nation is monstrously inadequate.

The Mansfield review of the ABC, whose recommendations the Howard government accepted, made its recommendations on the future of Radio Australia without taking into account the foreign policy dimensions of Radio Australia's operations. That is not my retrospective gloss on what occurred during that review; this was the subsequent admission of Mr Mansfield himself. My question is: what on earth was the Minister for Foreign Affairs doing at that time when such an extraordinary recommendation about the future of this 60-year-old institution was being made? The faint-hearted submission from the minister's department to the Mansfield review simply bleated about the possibility that Radio Australia may no longer be as effective as it once was.

But the icing on the cake of the government's culpable negligence in this matter was Senator Alston's statement not only that Radio Australia was expendable but also that the short-wave broadcast technology in which it specialised had become obsolete. This was a most remarkable statement, given that every other significant international broadcaster—the BBC, Voice of America, Radio Netherlands, Radio Japan and Deutsche Welle—is increasing, not decreasing, its expenditure on short-wave broadcast capacity. It may be that in the developed world short wave is being supplanted by other communications technologies, but in developing Asia it certainly is not. Within Indonesia itself, short wave is not regarded as anything exotic in terms of getting news from overseas; it is regarded as the normal means by which you access a large number of domestic radio broadcasts.

The government, in justifying its emasculation of Radio Australia, often talks about the possible use of other new technologies and methodologies to get Radio Australia's message out to the region. Reference is made to satellite technology, transmission lease and hire, program sales and retransmission and the Internet. Of course, all these are part of the future of international communications strategy, but none possess the capacity of short-wave transmission now in developing Asia. We have had a number of parliamentary committees look at this. A joint parliamentary committee recommended on a bipartisan basis that the Cox Peninsula transmitters be reopened for Radio Australia and that its programming budget be restored. The Cox facility has been idle now for two years for Radio Australia. Cox is now subject to expressions of interest from those interested around the world in a lease of its facilities. It will then go out to tender.

My call today to the government is simply this: learn from the mistakes that have been committed in the past on this matter, address the exigencies which now arise as a result of the East Timor crisis, cancel this process of selling or leasing out Cox to the highest bidder and restore the budget of Radio Australia so that we can have a capacity once again to provide services to the region and to Australian nationals within it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise this afternoon in the grievance debate to highlight certain issues regarding Queensland Health that are of particular concern to me and my electorate of Leichhardt. These issues are numerous but, given that I am limited to 10 minutes, I will go through only four or five that at the moment are particularly pressing and which I think we should be made aware of.

speech.para: The first relates to a problem associated with the recent allocation or appointment of a third doctor to the Cooktown Hospital. That appointment was carried out under a federal government initiative which was implemented last year. Under that initiative, doctors in rural and remote areas were allowed to bulkbill indigenous patients, with the rebates then being paid directly to the local district health service to be used to support an additional doctor. That was an outstanding success in the Cooktown district which not only incorporates the Gowangardie community but also has the Wujal Wujal and Hopevale communities close by plus the farming community of Lakeland Downs and Rossville and other small communities. The appointment of a third doctor meant that for the first time a doctor was able to be sent out to these communities and, as a consequence, access to medical practitioners increased dramatically. There is no question that, as a direct result of that increase, a significant improvement was had with regard to a number of serious health issues.

However, in January this year the third doctor decided to leave Cooktown and Queensland Health, in its wisdom, decided not to replace her. Her contract expired on 30 April, so from January to April there was no third doctor there—and, of course, the community paid the penalty for that. At that point in time, Queensland Health decided that it would not appoint a third doctor. The reason it gave at that stage was the suggestion that the federal government had withdrawn the program. That was blatantly dishonest, which we proved very, very quickly. Pauline Gray from the Health Action Group of Cooktown fought a very valiant campaign in having that position of doctor reinstated with the full support of the local community. After we had proved the inaccuracy of its suggestion, Queensland Health then came back and basically said that there was an additional cost there that it could not afford; that the Medicare rebates were not covering its costs. But, with community support, eventually on 25 May Queensland Health relented and, as a consequence, that position of third doctor was retained.

However, we are now fighting a similar battle in Weipa where two of the three doctors are leaving. Queensland Health has decided that it cannot afford to fully replace those two doctors and it will be replacing two doctors with one. Weipa is a community of several thousand.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware of the problems we have in Aboriginal communities like Napranum and Mapoon of large Aboriginal populations with serious health problems. Queensland Health is removing the private service completely and the area will have only two instead of three doctors. There is a hospital in Weipa where there are about 16 patients at any given time and there is all the after-hours work plus, as I said, several thousand people in the area, plus tourists and everything else. It is an absolutely impossible situation and it is little wonder that doctors just cannot cope with staying in the area. But Queensland Health has decided it will not fund that position.

I am pleased to see that a campaign has now been orchestrated by the local communi ty in Weipa. Joanne McDermid is organising it, and we have a petition with some 400 concerned residents having signed up so far. We are hoping that commonsense will prevail and we will be able to reinstate the third doctor into the Weipa community. It is something that is absolutely desperately needed, and I would encourage very strongly Queensland Health to give some serious consideration to doing it sooner rather than later.

While we are talking about Weipa, I would also suggest that Queensland Health start working a little harder to have installed a dialysis unit funding was approved for probably two years ago. Queensland Health is still playing politics and trying to sort out the logistics of it. In the meantime the Weipa community is still waiting for that $1 million dialysis machine all because Queensland Health cannot sort out issues or is not prepared to come to the table and finalise negotiations. I think that two years is a long time for any community to wait for something as important as dialysis.

We all know how important problems associated with renal failure are in Aboriginal communities. At this point in time, people from the West Cape York communities have to travel to Cairns. In effect, the only way they can travel back to their communities is in a coffin. They have no support. There are no facilities in Weipa to undertake dialysis at the moment. As a consequence, these people, once they are unfortunate enough to contract this illness, are being condemned forever to being away from their communities. Given that the money has been available for two years, it is about time that Queensland Health got around to resolving this issue to make sure that these people can stay within their communities.

Another issue too with regard to Queensland Health: on 10 September I had a very distressing phone call from a Mrs Bonetti from Mossman. She had just travelled down from Mossman to Cairns for her husband to be admitted for a prostate operation. He had been waiting for some three months and had had the operation cancelled twice before. Being a shift worker at the Mossman mill, he made arrangements to change shifts to come down and have the operation. He had psyched himself up for it. He was very concerned about the long-term ramifications of this condition, whether or not it was likely to be malignant. He had been wearing a catheter and a bag for some three months or more. When he arrived at the hospital to check in for surgery, basically he was told that it had been cancelled, that they had no record of him there and that he would have to leave and come back at some other stage.

He was very distressed and so was his wife. They were almost frantic in trying to deal with this issue, given that twice before he had been booked in, he had gone down and on both occasions he had been told to go away and to come back again. Clearly, there are serious problems there with regard to waiting lists and surgery bookings, and I ask Queensland Health to take into consideration the impact this has on families like the Bonettis. It is unreasonable for them to travel that sort of distance with an expectation and then to be turned away at the last moment. I ask that the issue be dealt with very quickly.

In the few minutes that I have left, I want to raise another issue relating to that area concerning the Mossman nursing home. For about nine years now the Mossman community has been trying to establish a nursing home. The President of the Mossman Nursing Home Committee, Marj Norris, and the secretary, Shirley Vico, have been tireless fighters, as was the late Bob Gray before his recent demise. His memory has been carried on by his wonderful wife, Joan, in trying to achieve this.

Earlier this year I was able to get a commitment from the federal Minister for Aged Care, Bronwyn Bishop, for some 15 high-care places, worth about $400,000. It is going to take a little time, but they are trying to open up a wing that has been refurbished in the Mossman hospital. Unfortunately neither the minister, Wendy Edmonds, nor the local state member, Steve Bredhauer, have taken the time to have a look at this—they have discarded it out of hand, suggesting that it is totally inappropriate.

I call on both Mr Bredhauer and Wendy Edmonds to take the time to have a look at the facility. It would be an excellent short-term facility that would prevent people from being taken out of their community and relocated to Cairns and areas further south while a more appropriate facility is being built. I encourage them to take the time to have a look at it so the money can stay within the community and, more importantly, so that older Australians who desperately want to stay in the community can do so.

subdebateinfo.title: Charlton Electorate: Kirinari Hostel
Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders: Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak today about Aboriginal reconciliation. The steps towards reconciliation in our communities and in our country can take many and varied forms. In my electorate there is an Aboriginal students' hostel named Kirinari. Kirinari comes from the Awabakal language and means `place of learning'. Kirinari is a very important facility for Aboriginal boys attending high school. With accommodation for 14 students, it draws students from all over New South Wales, generally from very isolated communities. They attend Cardiff High School and interact with the local community through students from a variety of backgrounds.

speech.para: There are currently seven students living at Kirinari. They range in ages and attend grades 7 to 10 at high school. Mal and Noelene Honess are the house parents at Kirinari, and they have been living there for 5½ years. It is funded under the Aboriginal Hostels Program and is a project of the Aboriginal Children's Advancement Society. But, as we consistently find with many Commonwealth government funded organisations which provide real and ongoing benefits to our community, such as schools and hospitals, Kirinari receives only enough funding to survive. The hardworking houseparents and the commitment of those young men to successfully continue and complete their schooling is the main reason for its continued successful operation.

On Friday afternoon I attended a cleansing ceremony at Kirinari to mark the beginning of the construction of a `SHED'. The first sod was turned by two year 10 students, Joshua Gristwood and Paul Gordon. The Kirinari SHED should be completed by the start of the school year in 2000.

Let me go back to the beginning. Early in 1996, the Hon. Bob Brown, the former member for Charlton, was alerted to the fact that the boys at Kirinari had nowhere to exercise or to participate in handcraft or woodwork activities for school projects. Kirinari is a delightful place. It is set amongst bush at Garden Suburb and built on the land of the Awabakal people, who are the original owners and custodians of that land. As well as the accommodation there are communal living and meal areas. There is also a half-size basketball court which is in high demand. These students are avid sportsmen and are regularly appraised by the Knights for their League prowess.

There is no covered indoor area available for the activities previously mentioned. In November 1996 Bob Brown launched the Kirinari SHED Appeal, with the slogan `every boy needs a SHED'. The acronym `SHED' stands for Student Handcraft and Exercise Den. The appeal committee was comprised of Bob Brown; Trevor Swann, the Principal of Cardiff High School; Warren Smiles of the Newcastle Knights; Brian Suters of Suters Architects; Barry Grainger, representing Stronachs builders; and Frank Gorrel from the Aboriginal Children's Advancement Society was the treasurer. Alby Lamond, from Herd, designed the SHED. The appeal was launched formally on 2 November 1996 at an open day at Kirinari. I was pleased to be involved in those earlier times, and I am also pleased to continue that support now as the federal member.

The appeal kicked off with some very generous donations and `in kind' support. As it progressed, we wrote to many local national and multinational corporations for financial contributions. Although I will not name any of the organisations we approached—and I know many of them do have their own donating provisions—I was extremely disappointed and alarmed that none of them could donate a few thousand dollars to help these young boys in my electorate with their education. The Prime Minister had better take note in regard to his social coalition policy because there will be many Australian people and communities absolutely devastated if the wealthiest in the country cannot support those who this government is deserting. I appeal now to any businesses, large or small, to contact me so that they can make a donation towards this extremely worthy cause. Such a generous gesture on their part would be a positive contribution to the reconciliation process. Please contact me; we do need your assistance to complete the SHED.

During the appeal, we were promised a one-off grant from Aboriginal Hostels Australia of $50,000 if we raised as much privately. However, by mid 1997 we still had only our original small contributions, which were being steadily eaten away by various costs. We then had the news that a lady named Ruby Ellen Binns, who had passed away in 1986, had bequeathed her estate to an Aboriginal organisation which was no longer in existence and that Kirinari, along with two other Aboriginal groups, would be submitted to the state attorney-general as a possible recipient for those funds. At this stage, I want to thank and acknowledge Helen Richards from the New South Wales aboriginal affairs department for keeping us fully informed and up to date regarding any possible avenues for funding.

In early 1998, we were advised by the state attorney-general that he had approved nearly $75,000 from Ruby Ellen Binns's estate to be allocated to the Kirinari SHED project. On Saturday 23 May 1998, the Hon. Richard Face MP, state member for Charlestown, presented a cheque for $72,369.21 to Bob as the chair of the appeal committee. At this time, Aboriginal Hostels pledged its $50,000 toward the project.

None of us in the SHED project at Kirinari have any idea who Ruby Ellen Binns was. I take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who may have known this remarkable woman, or who may have had some contact with her or her family, to call me. It is vital that we know more about the woman who, in 1986, left around a quarter of a million dollars of her estate for the advancement of Aboriginal people. The organisation which she originally named in her will was disbanded in 1979; this means that she made the original bequest prior to 1979. This was a period when Aboriginal children were still being forcibly removed from their families and communities, they were still living in substandard housing without adequate hygiene or running water, and many of the children did not even attend school. It had been only 10 years since Aboriginal adults were given the right to vote, and they had only recently had their rights to their land recognised with the Northern Territory Land Rights Act. Yet here was a woman—who at some stage was living with her sister, a Mrs Elliott, in Birdwood Street, Lambton in the inner suburbs of Newcastle—who wanted to do what she could for Aboriginal people. But no-one seems to know of her. Ruby did not leave this money for public recognition or someone would know of her.

We do know that Ruby was born on 18 January 1901, and her birth name was Jarrett. She died on 10 April 1986. We also know that she owned some real estate at Yerrinbool, near Moss Vale. Ruby was living at the Betheden Nursing Home in Cardiff when she passed away. Other than those very few details, we know little about her, and further inquiries have not been enlightening. If anybody listening today has ever been acquainted with Ruby or has any information about her, I would be very pleased to hear from you. I particularly want to ensure that the name of Ruby Ellen Binns and the contribution she made for the good of the community are recognised and preserved.

I particularly want to do this this year, as we as a nation are progressing towards true reconciliation with our indigenous people. During these times when a national consultative process is occurring to produce a document of reconciliation, it is necessary that, as a part of the process, these meaningful gestures from Ruby and many others are recognised and their value acknowledged.

In the short time I have left, I want to talk about a contribution being made by many of my constituents to the draft reconciliation document. The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, in the process of public consultation, had no plans to hold any forums in the Lake Macquarie and Newcastle areas. I have therefore organised a forum to discuss the draft document, and I am pleased that my colleague, Mr Daryl Melham, the shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs and the shadow minister for reconciliation, has agreed to facilitate the forum.

I am extremely pleased that I have so far received acceptances from about 50 representatives from organisations, including schools, ex-service associations, Aboriginal land councils, local government, the United Nations Association, religious organisations, child-care centres, neighbourhood centres, youth groups, trade unions and ALP branches. I look forward to the forum and the contribution that we will make to the continuing process of reconciliation in our community.

talk.start.para: —In my last grievance speech, I brought before this House the problem of the increasing use of illicit drugs amongst our young people. I do not believe that there is another problem facing the nation today as alarming to parents as the increasing use of illicit drugs. Not only does the use of illicit substances cause death, suicide, mental and physical illness, depression and misery to countless thousands; it also impacts upon families and the wider community in the most tragic way.

speech.para: I want to record my congratulations to the Prime Minister and this government for the serious and continuous commitment it makes to the young people of this nation through the government's innovative Tough on Drugs strategy. This commitment is reflected in the $516 million allocated over the next four years to important health related drug strategies. However, confusion surrounds the policies with which all governments, with the exception of the Northern Territory government, have addressed the illicit drug issue since 1985. I am encouraged that our Prime Minister now uses terms like `prevention' and `early intervention'. This leads me to believe that there is a significant change at executive level in how our government will progress this issue in future.

For the past 15 years, governments have had a drug policy called `harm minimisation'. This policy begins with the premise that all children will experiment with drugs, so society should teach them how to do it with safety, minimising the harm they will experience. This policy includes initiatives like the methadone program, needle distribution, heroin trials, so-called `safe shooting galleries' and safe use education in our schools. Thankfully, our government has recently introduced a total prevention and early intervention program in our schools as part of its Tough on Drugs strategy.

The harm minimisation policy is not aimed at reducing drug use at all. It does not seek to encourage young people to live drug-free lives. It sends a message to our young people that drugs can be okay, as long as you use them responsibly. As the parents in my electorate are well aware, this is a load of dangerous codswallop, and I think it is about time we faced up to the glaring fact that the harm minimisation strategy of the past 15 years has failed. In the face of the increasing use of illicit drugs in Australia, there is no other conclusion. For the past 15 years, there have been many bureaucrats and health professionals in our government agencies who are paid a lot of money to make sure that we get it right.

It is high time we asked for some new options and had a fresh look at other strategies, especially a look at the strategies in those countries which have a successful track record of decreasing drug use amongst their populations. We do not have to look too far. I refer to the successful and effective anti-tobacco campaign which markedly reduced consumption here in Australia. We all clearly understand that there is no safe way to smoke tobacco, and the messages to the Australian public sent by this campaign were strong and clear on this point.

However, despite the successful `no' campaign against tobacco, there are still intransigent people in key positions in government health departments who continue to peddle the outrageous idea that people can take drugs safely. But the vast majority of parents across Australia understand that there is no safe way for their children to use illicit drugs, and want the government to implement policies which will help their children lead drug free lives. I refer to policies which encourage prevention and, like tobacco, total abstinence in the first instance—policies which tell kids `Just don't start.' This aspect of the Tough on Drugs strategy has been warmly welcomed.

In my last speech on this subject, I raised the issue of bias in the media in favour of the harm minimisation perspective. The media bias against those who argue in favour of a policy of harm prevention and demand reduction through total abstinence has not greatly improved. Again, because I think it is so important that the parents of Australia are aware, I repeat the extract from the speech by Mr Bill Stronach, the then Executive Director of the Alcohol and Drug Foundation of Victoria, to the International Conference on Drug Policy Reform in Washington in 1992 when he said:
The harm caused by illicit drugs is minuscule compared to legal drugs.

But if one takes into account the depression, mental illness and suicide as well as other related deaths due to illicit drugs, there is a very wide debilitating and tragic impact upon the broader Australian community through illicit drug use. Leading authorities on this subject directly attribute the use of illicit drugs with depression, mental illness and suicide, and I refer the House to the work of Dr John Anderson of the Neuroscience Psychological Services at Westmead in Sydney.
In his address in 1992, Mr Stronach referred to the current drug policy, stating:
. . . We have employed journalists not to churn out press releases but to get in there as subversives and work with their colleagues in the mainstream press.
