talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 21 June 1999:

question.para: (1) What sum was raised from the partial privatisation of Telstra.
(2) How has the sum referred to in part (1) been allocated.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The total sum raised from the partial privatisation (1st Tranche) of Telstra was $14.2 billion .

(2) When the Government announced the sale of one third of Telstra, we signalled our intent to use the proceeds to retire Government debt and to use $1.149 billion to create the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Reserve. The creation of the Trust was formally announced as a Budget Measure in the 1997-98 Budget.
Since receiving $14.2 billion by way of sale proceeds in two instalments, the Government has used the funds to retire debt with more than $16 billion of debt being repaid in 1997-98 alone*.
As stated, $1.149 billion has been appropriated to the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Reserve with $402.6 million being drawn from the Trust as at 30 June 1999.
(* source—consolidated financial statements to 30 June 1998 General Govt Sector figure)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to claims that in recent years individuals and companies may have been wrongly granted plant breeder's rights.
(2) Has his attention also been drawn to claims involving the granting of plant breeder's rights for Australian native species.

(3) Is it a fact that (a) plant breeder's rights were granted for a variety of waratah called `Cardinal' in 1994 and (b) the variety was known to exist in 1955 and was recognised as a variety of common knowledge before the enactment of the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987; if so, will the grant be revoked.
(4) Will he investigate whether plant breeder's rights are being granted wrongly and examine the role of the Plant Breeder's Rights Office and the Plant Breeder's Rights Act 1994 itself.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (3) (a) Plant variety rights were granted to `Cardinal' under the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987 (the PVR Act) as the result of an application lodged in 1994.

(b) `Cardinal' may have been recognised as a distinctive form of waratah before the enactment of the PVR Act. However, neither the recognition of its distinctiveness or the publication of its description in 1988 automatically disqualifies it from protection.

There are legislative mechanisms to appeal the granting of rights and I understand that a formal request for revocation of the registration of `Cardinal' has been made. This request is being considered in accordance with the PVR Act. Therefore it is not possible at this time to advise whether the grant of rights will be revoked or not.
(4) There is general acknowledgment that the Plant Breeder's Rights Act 1994 (the PBR Act) is operating effectively although, like all regulatory systems, it is subject to periodic refinement.

Australia's PBR Act is administered in conformity with the international standards established under the Union for the Protection of New Varieties of Plants (UPOV). The PBR Act specifically includes formal mechanisms to object to a grant of rights where there is evidence to show that the variety does not meet the statutory requirements. There are legitimate objections to the granting of rights under the PBR Act in only about 1% of all applications.

The PBR Act also establishes an industry committee to advise me on the operation of the PBR Act. I have no cause as a consequence of the committee's advice, or from proven objections, to institute a review of the role of the Plant Breeder's Rights Office or the PBR Act itself.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Has the Government consulted with the States about ratification of ILO Convention 173, Part 111, Protection of Workers Claims by a Guarantee Institution; if so, what consultation has been undertaken.

(2) Will the Government use the external affairs power of the Constitution to enact legislation to give effect to a wage earner protection fund, based on ILO Convention 173, Part 111, Protection of Workers Claims by a Guarantee Institution.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Consultations occurred with the State and Territory Governments concerning ILO Convention No 173 in relation to the ratification process in 1993-94. The then Labor government was only in a position to accept Part II of the Convention. No consultations in relation to Part III were undertaken. Australian law in 1993-94 would not have enabled such ratification of Part III.

(2) The Government is taking action not taken by previous Labor governments to extend the protection afforded to employee entitlements in the event of employer insolvency. Legislation relating to the Oakdale and Merrywood miners situation is already in the Parliament. In addition, the Government is examining the establishment of a national safety net scheme to deal with the issues more generally and has issued a discussion paper for comment. Proposals to amend the Corporations law have also been announced. The Government does not need to use the external affairs power to achieve these objectives.

subdebateinfo.title: International Labour Convention on Child Labour: Australian Involvement
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 825)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: Further to question No. 577 (Hansard , 9 August 1999, page 6322), did Australia, at the June 1999 International Labour Conference, vote in favour of a new Convention and Recommendation on the worst forms of child labour; if so, will the Government pursue the early ratification of the Convention.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: At the June 1999 International Labour Conference, all four Australian delegates (ie, two government, one employer and one worker) voted in favour of the adoption of a new Convention and Recommendation on the worst forms of child labour.

The question of ratification of the new Convention will be considered within the established framework for consultation and cooperation between the Commonwealth, States and Territories. Consultations will commence after the official text of the Convention is received from the ILO (expected September 1999). In accordance with normal practice, the views of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Australian Council of Trade Unions will be sought as will the views of the State and Territory Governments.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 678 (Hansard , 9 August 1999, page 6338), concerning the Government's indigenous employment policy, has the Government continued to fund the operations of indigenous employment managers with the ACTU; if not, why not.

(2) Has the Government had discussions with representatives of ACCI concerning the possibility of extending the placement of indigenous employment managers with ACCI beyond the expiration of the current contract in December 1999.
(3) Will the Government continue to place indigenous employment managers with employer or union organisations.

(4) Is he able to say whether indigenous employment managers placed with ACCI to assist in creating employment opportunities for indigenous people devote time to recruiting members to ACCI; if so, is this an appropriate use of taxpayer funds; if not, will he ensure that the practice ceases.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No. The arrangement with the ACTU was part of a national agreement incorporating eight employees operating as Aboriginal Employment Development Officers (AEDOs) with ACTU affiliates in the States and the Northern Territory and the funding of a National Coordinator position in the Trade Union Training Authority (TUTA). I am advised that an independent evaluation of these arrangements in 1996 identified a number of problems with the implementation of the project and its cost effectiveness. These included an inability to clearly identify employment outcomes, problems with the relationship between the AEDO network and agencies like the Commonwealth Employment Service, and with the supervision of AEDOs by ACTU affiliates. At the same time a restructure of TUTA meant that a nationally coordinated strategy was not appropriate. State Managers of my Department were asked to consider local agreements based on the value of the previous agreement in terms of job outcomes. With the exception of the contract with the Queensland Trades and Labour Council, the Department's State Managers chose not to proceed with local agreements. The contract with the Queensland Trades and Labour Council was extended until 30 June 1997 and finalised at that time.

(2) The current contract with the ACCI is due to expire on 31 December 1999. The ACCI has approached my Department to discuss the possibility of a further agreement but no commitment has been made at this stage by either party.
(3) Proposals would be considered on a case by case basis.
(4) The ACCI has advised that its network of Indigenous Employment Managers funded by my Department does not promote membership of the ACCI or its affiliated chambers and associations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: Does his Department have evidence that Australia's visa regime and visitor visa policy is having a negative impact on the number of persons seeking to visit Australia; if so, does detailed information exist to show the extent to which visas are a motivating factor in a traveller's decision on which travel destination is selected.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: No evidence has been provided to my Department that Australia's visa regime and visitor visa policy is having a negative impact on the number of persons seeking to visit Australia. The 1996 report by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration inquiry into Australia's Visa System for Visitors states that " claims from the tourism industry were not supported by concrete evidence. The committee requested but was not presented with any detailed information to show the extent to which visas are a motivating factor in a traveller's decision as to which travel destination is selected." This situation remains unchanged.

Although the numbers of visitor visas issued during 1998 fell from 3.08m in 1997 to 2.90m in 1998 (an overall fall of 175,000 or 5.7%), There is no evidence that Australia's visa regime or visitor policy has been the cause of this reduction in numbers.

Of our top 20 source countries for visitors in 1998, eight had fewer visas issued in 1998 than in 1997. Of these eight countries, four (Korea, Malaysia, Japan and Sweden) are existing Electronic Travel Authority (ETA) countries, where my Department does not impose an application charge and most visitor visas are issued electronically at the same time as the client purchases their airline ticket. From these countries we experienced a reduction of 230,000 visitor visas in 1998.
From the four countries that were non-ETA countries at the time, (Indonesia, Philippines, Taiwan and Thailand) we experienced a reduction of 84,000 visitor visas in 1998.

Seven of the eight countries are in the Asian region and in all these cases the fall in the number of visas issued commenced in late 1997. This was at the start of the economic downturn in the region and over 6 months before the introduction of the visa charge for non-ETA countries.

In most non-ETA countries, our tourism destination competitors also require visas for entry and charge a visa fee that is either on a par with, or higher than, Australia's. Their approach to processing visitor visa applications out of high risk countries is also broadly similar to Australia's.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Does his Department's approach to processing visitor visa applications vary from country to country; if so, why.

(2) Does departmental data suggest that nationals of some countries have a greater propensity to apply under the Migration Regulations for an extended stay in Australia than do nationals of other countries.
(3) Is there a view in his Department that visitors from some countries deliberately seek to mislead departmental officers into granting a visitor visa and then seek to change status on-shore.

(4) Is there evidence that persons from a particular country who apply on-shore to change their status pursue the protection visa stream; if so, what is the (a) success rate and (b) average cost to the Department of processing those applications.
(5) Are there major differences in the health and character checks undertaken by his Department between applications for visitor visas and applications for permanent residence.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The legal criteria that must be met before a visitor visa to enter Australia can be granted are the same for all nationalities. The approach to processing visitor visa applications does vary from country to country. Objective, statistical data collected on all visitor arrivals shows that persons with certain characteristics relating to nationality, gender and age have a greater propensity to overstay the period of stay authorised or apply for a further visa. This information is relevant feedback to decision-makers at overseas posts and is used along with the information provided by clients in decisions on visitor visa applications.

(2) Data does suggest that nationals of some countries have a greater propensity to apply under the Migration Regulations for an extended stay in Australia than do nationals of other countries. In 1997/98, 1.8% of all people who arrived in Australia on a visitor visa subsequently lodged another visa application. For some countries within the top 50 source countries of visitors to Australia, this rate was as high as 20%, for other countries it was as low as 0.1%. This rate does not include those who remain in Australia unlawfully beyond the validity of their visa.

(3) In order to obtain a visitor visa, applicants are required to present evidence to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs decision-makers that they have every intention of departing Australia before the expiry of their visitor visa. In recognition of the fact that people's circumstances do change, the Migration Regulations do have provisions to allow visitors to seek an extension of their stay after arrival or to change status to permanent residence. However, when data shows that visitors from certain countries use these provisions at a rate up to 10 times the global average, then decision-makers must question the veracity of the evidence presented regarding an intention to make a genuine visit.

Also relevant is the extent to which applicants from some countries present fraudulent documentation and false claims. The examples of fraudulent documentation decision-makers have observed range from simple "whiting- out of names" through to extremely sophisticated use of photographic technology.

(4) Evidence suggests that persons from a number of countries pursue the protection visa route when applying on-shore to change their status. Protection visa applications from 190 countries were processed in 1998/99.

(a) The ten largest source countries for protection visas (with primary approval rates in brackets) were Indonesia (0.12%), China (0.73%), Sri Lanka (17.63%), Philippines (0%), Iraq (76.75%), India (0.54%), Republic of Korea (0%), Malaysia (0%), Thailand (1.1%) and Iran (35.75%).

(b) The average approval rate for all protection visa primary applications in 1998/99 was 13.7%. The average cost to my Department of processing protection visa applications is estimated to be $2529 per application in 1999/2000. This processing cost is for applicants who remain in the community during processing and does not include other associated costs such as detention, legal aid, asylum seekers assistance, representations and requests for Ministerial intervention.

(5) Yes, there are differences in the health and character checks undertaken by my Department between applications for visitor visas and applications for permanent residence. The health requirement for short-term visitors is generally met by a self-declaration that they do not suffer from any communicable diseases. This is a risk management approach that assumes because visitors will be in Australia for only a short period of time, the risks to public health can be managed. However, for persons coming to Australia on a long-term or permanent basis or who will be engaged in an activity of special significance for health, such as visiting a hospital or a school, we undertake extensive health testing overseas before a visa is granted. This enables my Department to ensure that any relevant disease is treated off-shore and, once the disease is stabilised, that the person undertakes to report to health authorities on arrival in Australia.

Character checking for visitors is based essentially on the Movement Alert List (MAL) and self-declaration. For persons applying for permanent residence, more extensive penal and other checks are undertaken, based on the countries of residence of the applicant over the last 10 years.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 11 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Does Telstra have an arrangement with a Melbourne-based company, United Customer Management Solutions Pty Ltd (UCMS), for UCMS to communicate with Telstra customers on financial matters, including the provision of refunds on UCMS cheques.
(2) What is the basis of the financial arrangements between Telstra and UCMS.
(3) Does Telstra pay a fee to UCMS to handle Telstra business with customers; if so why.
(4) Are privacy provisions in place to protect Telstra customers from a breach of their rights to privacy in their relationship with their provider; if so, what.

(5) Does UCMS provide full details of the origins of cheque refunds sent to customers in order to avoid confusion over what might appear to be a windfall cheque from an unknown source, if not, why not.
(6) Does UCMS provide telephone contact numbers on documents sent to Telstra customers to enable customers to follow-up inquiries; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Pursuant to the Service Provider Agreement, UCMS provides services, including billing and credit management services, to certain specified Telstra mobile service customers. In some circumstances, these services may require UCMS to issue refunds to customers.
(2) UCMS is paid a fee for the services it provides. The fee is calculated by reference to amounts received by Telstra from the customers to whom UCMS provides services.

(3) UCMS provides, under contract to Telstra, various customer management services to certain specified Telstra customers. In accordance with normal commercial practice, UCMS is paid a fee by Telstra for providing these services.

(4) The treatment of personal information of Telstra customers (including customers to whom UCMS is contracted to provide services) is subject to the provisions of Part 13 of the Telecommunications Act, Telstra's Privacy Protection Policy and, to the extent that it is applicable, the Privacy Act. Telstra takes its obligations in relation to privacy of customer information extremely seriously and has adopted comprehensive policies and procedures to ensure compliance.
UCMS is subject to both statutory and contractual obligations to Telstra requiring it to respect the privacy of customer information.

Customers to whom UCMS provides services have consented to the provision of those services and may, if they wish, withdraw that consent and request that the relevant services be provided directly by Telstra.

(5) UCMS is obliged to provide the relevant services to Telstra customers in an efficient and professional manner. Detailed procedures in relation to, for example, the payment of refunds are a matter for UCMS to determine. However, Telstra would expect that refund cheques provided by UCMS to Telstra customers to whom UCMS provides services, will be accompanied by explanatory material and Telstra understands that this is the case.

(6) Again, UCMS is obliged to provide the relevant services to Telstra customers in an efficient and professional manner. Telstra would expect that material sent to Telstra customers to whom UCMS provides services will include a UCMS customer inquiries telephone number and Telstra understands that this is the case.
